bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 9, 1899

div1.p: Lazear reports on the health of Mabel Lazear and their child.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 9, 1899
div1.opener:
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
OFFICE HOURS
4.30-6 P.M.
BALTIMORE. July 9 99
My dear Mother,-
div1.p:
I hope you can read this but
if you cant, it is your own fault because
I am writing with a pen and ink I
found in your room.

We have been fortunate in having very
pleasant weather lately and I hope it
will continue at any rate until I leave
which will probably be in a very few
days. I shall probably stay over
night in New York and go up to
Hatley by daylight. I find I can
go now as well as at any time and
I am a little tired. It does not pay
to work all summer in this climate.
The house here is rather deserted.
Frances is visiting Miss Wall but expects
to return on Saturday. Thomas also will
come back from the Eastern Shore this week.
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
OFFICE HOURS
4.30-6 P.M.
BALTIMORE.
Alex of course has not yet reached Liverpool.
His steamer is the “Indore” you might
look out for its arrival at Liverpool
in the skipping notices in the “Sun.”
She ought to be in in a few days.

Aunt Kate got a letter from him written
on the bay. Hes said his quarters were
comfortable and the food good.

I am glad to hear the Mabel and the baby have
recovered from their colds. It is
maybe to have a cold at this time
of the year.
